Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 53104-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2019 
 
 
 
Timor-Leste: Implementing Reforms for Growth and 
Competitiveness
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
 
The currency unit of Timor-Leste is the United States dollar. 
 
 
 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  BNCTL  –  Banco Nacional de Comércio de Timor-Leste (National 
    Commercial Bank of Timor-Leste) 
GDP  –  gross domestic product 
SERVE  –  Serviço de Registo e Verificação Empresarial (Business 
    Registration and Verification Service) 
SOE  –  state-owned enterprise 
TA  –  technical assistance  
   
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars.

1 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Implementing Reforms for Growth and Competitiveness is a knowledge and support 
technical assistance (TA) that will help Timor-Leste to become more economically competitive. 
The TA will support the corporatization of water and electricity services and help reduce the 
transaction costs faced by private businesses. The TA is aligned with the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030 operational priority 6 on strengthening governance and institutional 
capacity and operationalizes ADB’s commitment to implementing a differentiated approach in 
small island developing states and fragile and conflict-affected situations.1 The TA is included in 
ADB’s Timor-Leste country operations business plan, 2020–2022.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Growth slowdown. The 3-year moving average for non-oil gross domestic product (GDP) 
growth in Timor-Leste peaked at 10.4% in 2009 and has declined steadily since then. This 
slowdown is reflected in the slow pace of job creation and poverty reduction. In 2013, 59,000 
adults (9.5% of the working age population) were formally employed by private businesses. While 
average wages increased significantly during 2014–2017, formal employment has declined.3 As 
a  result,  only  8.4%  of  working-age  adults  had  formal  private  sector  employment  in  2017. 
Prospects for job creation and poverty reduction hinge on improved public sector efficiency and 
increased private investment. 
 
3.  Government effectiveness. Timor-Leste has made excellent progress in state building 
and institutional development. It has established core institutions and expanded access to basic 
services, including primary education, health care, and electricity. Assessments of government 
effectiveness  and  regulatory  quality  show  improvement,  but  the  overall  efficiency  and 
effectiveness of the public sector remains low.4 In-depth assessments of the government systems 
for public financial management and public investment that were carried out in 2016 and 2019 
also identified significant weaknesses.5 
 
4.   Institutional strengthening. The Program of the Eighth Constitutional Government, 
2018–2023 includes ambitious targets for growth and job creation through improved government 
effectiveness. Government reform efforts are organized under four main programs: (i) public 
administration  reform,  which  is  coordinated  by  the  Ministry  of  Legislative  Reform  and 
Parliamentary Affairs, (ii) fiscal and public financial management reform, which is coordinated by 
the Ministry of Finance (iii) decentralization reform, which is coordinated by the Ministry of State 
Administration, and (iv) legal and judicial reform, which is coordinated by the Ministry of Justice.  
 
5.  Stimulating growth. Improved government effectiveness would stimulate growth. The 
government is the major actor in the economy and public investment accounted for 80.3% of all 
 
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila; 
ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 6: Strengthening Governance and Institutional Capacity, 
2019–2024. Manila 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 27 September 2019; ADB. 
Forthcoming. Country Operations Business Plan: Timor-Leste, 2020–2022. Manila. 
3  Government of Timor-Leste. 2018. Business Activity Survey of Timor-Leste, 2017. Dili 
4  In 2017, Timor-Leste was placed in the 15th percentile on the government effectiveness dimension of the Worldwide 
Governance Indicators, and the 24th percentile for regulatory quality. Timor-Leste’s scores on both dimensions show 
some improvement since 2013 when it was ranked in the 9th percentile for government effectiveness and the 17th 
percentile for regulatory quality.   
5  International Monetary Fund. Timor-Leste Public Investment Management Assessment, 2016. Unpublished; and 
World Bank. Timor-Leste PEFA Assessment 2018. Unpublished.

2 
capital formation during 2007–2017. It is estimated that $1.3 billion of new investment will be 
needed to achieve universal access to sanitation and clean water.6 This includes investments in 
new infrastructure for water capture and treatment, water distribution, sanitation and wastewater 
treatment.  Limited capacity and inappropriate models for service delivery have reduced the 
efficiency of public investment. Implementing more appropriate service delivery models can help 
to improve the efficiency of public investment and asset utilization, thus contributing to growth. 
 
6.  Electricity and water services.  These services are currently managed as directorates 
general of the Ministry of Public Works and use general government systems for human resource 
management, planning, budgeting, and financial management. These systems are not well suited 
to the needs of a modern electricity or water utility. International experience has shown that 
restructuring public utilities as state-owned enterprises (SOEs) can help to improve efficiency and 
service quality.7 The government has committed to implementing a corporatization reform that 
would transform the electricity and water utilities into SOEs. Implementation of this reform will 
begin in 2020 and has excellent potential to improve asset management and service quality. 
However, ADB’s analysis of SOE performance in island countries shows that much of the benefit 
of corporatization is contingent on implementing good corporate governance.8 
 
7.  State owned enterprises. Timor-Leste’s 2003 Public Enterprise Law provides a legal 
framework for state-owned enterprises (SOEs). Reviews of this law and associated policies have 
identified several key gaps.9 Responsibility for SOE supervision is divided between the Ministry 
of Finance, line ministries (which supervise SOEs within their area of competence), and the 
Chamber of Accounts (which audits SOE accounts). Previous corporatization efforts failed to 
deliver the expected benefits. Independent assessments of the SOEs that manage drug supply, 
airports, and public broadcasting found that they failed to comply with their own statutes, lacked 
autonomy, and remained highly dependent on government funding.10 These issues point to the 
challenges  of  establishing  well-governed  and  effective  SOEs  in  Timor-Leste  and  highlight 
potential challenges with the planned corporatization of water and electricity services. ADB has 
shared  lessons  from  SOE  reform  in  the  Pacific  with  the  government  and  is  supporting 
development of a new SOE policy through a separate TA project.11  
 
8.  National Commercial Bank. The Banco Nacional de Comércio de Timor-Leste (BNCTL) 
is a state-owned financial institution. It was initially established as a microfinance institution and 
was restructured as a state-owned bank in 2011. ADB has been helping to address governance 
issues that emerged after the restructuring, including weak separation between the board of 
directors and management, and gaps in shareholder supervision. ADB helped prepare new 
bylaws for the bank that were approved in February 2019.12 Successful implementation of the 
 
6  Government of Timor-Leste. 2018. Sector Investment Plan 2018-2030 for Water Supply and Sanitation in Timor-
Leste. Dili 
7  Independent Evaluation Department. 2018. Thematic Evaluation: State-Owned Enterprise and Engagement Reform. 
Global Experience with State-Owned Enterprises Reforms. Manila: ADB. 
8  ADB. 2016. Finding Balance 2016: Benchmarking the Performance of State-Owned Enterprises in Island Countries. 
Manila. 
9  ADB. 2017. State-owned enterprises in Timor-Leste. Pacific Economic Monitor. Manila (December). pp. 16–18. 
10 M. Huff-Rousselle. 2009. Starting From Scratch in Timor-Leste: Establishing a Pharmaceutical and Medical Supplies 
System in a Post-Conflict Society. Health, Nutrition, and Population (HNP) Discussion Paper. Washington, DC: World 
Bank; and Government of Timor-Leste. 2014. Report 1/2014 – On-site verification of the Air Navigation Administration 
of Timor-Leste. Dili. 
11 ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for Fiscal Policy for Improved Service 
Delivery. Manila. (TA 9122-TIM). 
12 ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for Expansion of Financial Services. 
Manila (TA 8762-TIM).

3 
bylaws  would  help  to  create  a  model  of  good  corporate  governance  that  can  guide  the 
development of other SOEs in the country.  
 
9.  Stimulating private investment. Capital formation by private businesses in Timor-Leste 
averaged 5.8% of non-oil GDP during 2013–2017 compared to an average of 16.1% in Brunei 
Darussalam, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Thailand in 
2017.13 A range of factors contribute to low private investment, including the small domestic 
market, weak property rights, and difficulties in accessing  land, skilled labor, and credit.  It will 
take time to address these constraints, but facilitating business formation and new investment 
could yield immediate benefits. 
 
10.  Business registration. The Serviço de Registo e Verificação Empresarial (SERVE) was 
established  in  2012  as  a one-stop shop for  business  registration.  SERVE  administers the 
Commercial Companies Law, which was updated in 2017. These changes have resulted in 
improvements in Timor-Leste’s score on the starting a business dimension of the World Bank’s 
Doing  Business  indicators.14 However,  business  registration  continues  to  use  paper-based 
systems, which create opportunities for discretionary administrative actions and increase the risk 
of delays. SERVE is committed to implementation of an electronic company registry. However, 
significant work is needed before this reform can be implemented, including the review and 
updating of existing business processes. 
 
11.  Private investment. The government has worked to improve the regulation, promotion, 
and facilitation of investment. TradeInvest Timor-Leste is the designated government agency for 
the promotion and facilitation of investment by national and foreign investors. TradeInvest is 
responsible for administering Timor-Leste’s Private Investment Law, 2017,  and associated 
regulations.15 The law provides tax exemptions and other benefits to eligible investors, and 
mandates TradeInvest to help registered investors acquire all of the authorizations, permits, and 
registrations that are required to implement a new investment. TradeInvest is still at an early stage 
in developing capacity for investment facilitation. More effective facilitation of new investments 
could  increase  the  proportion  of  proposed  investments  that  are  implemented  by  helping 
businesses overcome administrative barriers and inefficiencies. Improved facilitation could also 
help the government to identify and resolve bottlenecks in business regulation. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
12.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) average non-oil GDP growth increased to 
7% per annum and; (ii) private investment increased by 10% per annum.16 The TA will have the 
following outcome: the quality of public utilities and business regulation improved.17 
 
13 World Bank. 2019. World Development Indicators 2019. Washington, DC. 
14 Timor-Leste’s score for the starting a business indicator increased from 15.94 in 2005 to 89.41 in 2019. This indicator 
is scored on a scale of 0–100, with larger numbers indicating improved performance. 
15 Government of Timor-Leste. 2017. Law 15/2017 – Private Investment Law. Dili; and Government of Timor-Leste. 
2018. Decree Law 2/2018 – Regulation of Procedures for Private Investment. Dili. 
16 Government of Timor-Leste. 2018. Program of the Eighth Constitutional Government, 2018–2023. Dili. 
17 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
13.  Output  1:  Governance  of  public  utilities  and  state-owned  financial  services 
improved. The TA will support the preparation, updating and implementation of work plans to 
transform the Directorate General for Water and Sanitation and Electricidade de Timor-Leste into 
SOEs. If successful, this transformation will lead to improved asset management, and more 
efficient and responsive service delivery.  The TA will support business planning for the new SOEs, 
the development of asset registers and balance sheets, analysis of SOE staffing and human 
resource needs, and development of corporate policies and other management tools. To ensure 
effective  coordination,  the  TA  will  help  the  government  to  prepare  and  regularly  update 
corporatization work plans. The government is currently confirming the availability of state budget 
resources to support the corporatization and may also mobilize additional grant-financed TA from 
other development partners.18 The work plans will include support that is funded by non-ADB 
sources and will include capacity development for the new SOEs and the government institutions 
that will be responsible for SOE supervision. Implementation of these work plans will be monitored 
by  transitional  ‘installation  committees’  that  the  government  is  establishing  to  coordinate 
corporatization.   
 
14.  The TA will provide follow-up capacity development support to the new corporate entities 
once they have become operational. This will include development of corporate systems and 
policies and training of key SOE personnel. The TA will also work with the government ministries 
that are responsible for BNCTL and the new water and electricity SOEs. The TA will support 
implementation of BNCTL’s bylaws and development of improved governance norms including 
the procedures for appointing board members, contracting community service obligations, and 
monitoring SOE performance.  
 
15.  Output 2: Transaction costs for private businesses reduced. The TA will review the 
Commercial Companies Law, 2017, and design and implement a work plan to improve business 
registration. The immediate focus will be on eliminating unnecessary inefficiencies and delays. 
The review will also map out a pathway to implementation of an electronic company registry and 
help identify resources to support this reform. The TA will support effective communication and 
dissemination of changes in business registration processes. It will also help TradeInvest to 
review and update its business processes for investment promotion and investment facilitation. 
 
16.  The TA will build on advisory support that has been provided through ADB’s TA on 
infrastructure  management  and  the  commercial  transformation  of  BNCTL.19 Evaluation  of 
previous TA support to Timor-Leste has highlighted that successful reform requires flexibility.20 
This is reflected in the indicative TA implementation period. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,600,000, of which (i) $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6) and (ii) $500,000 will be financed 
 
18 Potential providers of TA include the Government of Australia, the European Union, the Japan International 
Cooperation Agency, and the Millennium Challenge Corporation. 
19 ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for Expansion of Financial Services. 
Manila (TA 8762-TIM); and ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for Policy 
and Planning for Public Investments. Manila (TA 9495-TIM). 
20 ADB. 2019. Completion Report: Support for Preparation of a National Coffee Sector Development Plan for Timor-
Leste. Manila (TA 9264-TIM).

5 
on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund21 under the Water Financing Partnership Facility 
and administered by ADB.22 The government will provide counterpart support in the form of 
counterpart staff, office accommodation, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will administer the TA and will have full responsibility for disbursement of TA funds. 
ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; organize workshops; and provide quality 
assurance and coordination of all TA inputs. The Ministry of Legislative Reform and Parliamentary 
Affairs  will  be  the  TA  executing  agency  and  will  help  coordinate  TA  implementation  and 
concurrence on the consultants recruited by ADB. The Ministry of Public Works will be the 
implementing agency for output 1. SERVE and TradeInvest will be implementing agencies for 
output 2. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

19.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.23 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund under 
the Water Financing Partnership Facility and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to the Government of Timor-Leste for Implementing 
Reforms for Growth and Competitiveness, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
 
21 Financing partners: the governments of Australia, Austria, Norway, Spain, and Switzerland. 
22 Funds from the Water Financing Partnership Facility will be used for (i) background assessment of the water sector 
guided by the Asian Water Development Outlook framework methodology (2020) and (ii)  development and 
implementation of a corporatization work plan for the Directorate General for Water and Sanitation. 
23 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
